title: Energy of SHM - block dropped block-spring system

content.question: A block is attached to a horizontal spring and is initially at rest at the equilibrium position <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The block is then moved to position <math alttext="x equals negative A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>âˆ’</mo><mi>A</mi></mpadded></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and released from rest, undergoing simple harmonic motion. At the instant the block reaches position <math alttext="x equals positive A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mpadded><mi>A</mi></mpadded></math>, another identical block is dropped onto and sticks to the block, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. The two-block-spring system then continues to undergo simple harmonic motion. Which of the following correctly compares the total mechanical energy <math alttext="E sub total comma 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mrow><mtext>tot</mtext><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> of the two-block-spring system after the collision to the total mechanical energy <math alttext="E sub total comma 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mrow><mtext>tot</mtext><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></math> of the one-block-spring system before the collision?
